oai_dc:dc.dc:title: SIMULATIONS OF HURRICANE MATTHEW SURGE AND WAVES; COMPARISONS TO MEASUREMENTS
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Bender, Christopher
Kauppila, Ashley
Bredesen, Hunter
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Hurricane Matthew formed into a hurricane in the eastern Caribbean and rapidly intensified with peak intensity occurring in late September 2016 when the storm reached Saffir-Simpson Category 5 strength with 160 mph winds (Stewart, 2017). After leaving the Caribbean, Hurricane Matthew moved northward and remained close to the coasts of Florida, Georgia, South Carolina, and North Carolina and caused elevated water levels, large waves, and extensive coastal erosion.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Coastal Engineering Proceedings; No. 36 (2018): Proceedings of 36th Conference on Coastal Engineering, Baltimore, Maryland, 2018; waves.72
